instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message:
I have a 2011 13 inch MacBook Pro here. 
The MacBook runs super slow and fan runs on high. No knowledge of previous liquid damage, no sign of corrosion anywhere on the board. 

I heated the SMC to 150C but am still having the same problem. 
Ran ASD EFI and am getting ERROR - SMC IO failed. 

Help

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message:
It was failing Ts0P...I checked the trackpad connection and it was partially unplugged. 
I reseated the connection, ran the test again and it still failed. 
Going to replace the trackpad and see if that solves the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message: I replaced that trackpad, Ts0P is now passing, but the fan still runs high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message: This is what happens when you take out the heat guns before using the brains. Probably a fucked up SMC now, try rebelling it first.  though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message: I was having the same exact symptoms before and after. Should I still reball the SMC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message: Yes and that was probably only the dead trackpad! Now no one knows what is wrong, first suspect now would be SMC because it was fucked with.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message:
For the record I ran ASD before several times and it was passing before I heated the SMC. The only reason I heated the SMC is because I read a lot of posts here where that was recommended on this forum.
Lesson learned. Next time I'll ask before going for it. 

Anything else I should try before that or the next step is troubleshooting the SMC? 
I guess I'll reball or replace the SMC and let you know. 

Thanks master Duke

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> SMC issues
threads.message: Hmmm, actually ASD should fail on the fan!
